prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Resolving the Disk around W33a
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: With a resolution of 0.05'' (10 times better than our SMA-VEX data) and focussing on the disk tracing Band 6 CH3CN J=12-11 K=8 line we are aiming to spatially resolve the hot molecular emission from the disk and determine whether it is Keplerian.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Given the line we target is 6 km/s wide we can sufficiently resolve the velocity structure with a spectral resolution of 0.66 km/s. As we are probing two methyl cyanide ladders we also require the 937.5 MHz bandwidth. Therefore the ideal setup is the 937.5 MHz bandwidth with 0.66 km/s spectral resoltuion.
In addition we also target a range of methanol lines in the other two free basebands. From our previous observations 0.66 km/s spectral resolution is sufficient and also having a bandwidth of 937.5 MHz allows us to maximise the coverage of many methonal lines in the same band and give us a reasonable line free bandwidth for the continuum emission.

NOTE: Given the rules for only having a single non-standard baseline we have noticed although the technical hand book says CS36-7 in Band 6 has a resolution of 0.05'' and MRS of 0.65''. Our inputs of 50 mas resolution and a largest scale of 0.5'' in the Control and Performance section returns an error. We understand we are between the constraints of both non-standard configurations based on our representative frequency and angular scales. In order to conform to only one non-standard long baseline configuration we input a resolution of 50 mas and a slighly lower MRS of 0.49'' (compared with 0.5'' which we discuss in the proposal and below).
We want to resolve the disk around W33A on scales of 100 au. At the distance to the source we therefore require a resolution of 50 mas. We have previous experience with CARMA 2km baseline observations that achieve a spatial resolution of 100 au for another massive young stellar object S140-IRS1 where we are able to resolve the disk. Disk are expected to be a few hundred au in size, but <1000 au.
In our previous SMA-VEX observations with 0.5'' resolution the disk tracing CH3CN J=12-11 K=8 line is totally unresolved therefore as we focus on this line to understand the kinematics of the disk. We do not need any angular scales larger than 0.5'' as there is no disk emission from the K=8 line larger than this scale.

For this science goal we will fully probe the rotation structure in the disk around the massive protostar W33A. In order to do this we target known rotation tracers, the J=12-11 and J=13-12 CH3CN ladders. Specifically in our previous SMA-VEX data combined with our detailed 3D models the K=8 line in the ladder traces the disk and has an upper energy level of Eu=525 K.
We base our sensitivity requirements on our SMA-VEX data at 0.5'' resolution in combination with our detailed 3D radiative transfer line models (also see figure 2 of the attached proposal PDF for what the expected the moment one map for K=8 will look like).
In our previous observations K=8 has a peak of 130 mJy per 0.5'' beam per 0.6 km/s channel. A crude scaling of the beam sizes assuming uniform emission means at 50 mas with ALMA we would achieve a peak of only 1.3 mJy/beam per 0.6 km/s channel (beam ratio is 0.5^2/0.05^2). Using our model however we find that the emission is NOT uniformly distributed but more centrally peaked, this relates to a filling factor of at least 10. From this calculation we expect the peak to be 13 mJy/beam per 0.6 km/s channel.
Using CASA our simulated ALMA image with the CS36-7 configuration (50 mas resolution) we find the line peak at the source VLSR is 15 mJy/beam per 0.6 km/s channel. Note as below 0.6 km/s channels are sufficient to resolve the velocity structure of the line.
We need to fully resolve the velocity structure of this line. To do so we must detect channels with emission peaks at ~30% of the peak at VLSR (i.e. 30% of 15 mJy/bean/channel). Thus to be able to fully map everything above 5 sigma we need a sensitivity of 0.9 mJy/beam per 0.6 km/s channel. This is calculated via:
30% of the peak at VLSR = 15 * 0.3 = 4.5 mJy/beam/channel S/N of 5 in the channels whos peak is 4.5 mJy/beam/channel = 0.9 mJy/beam/channel (9 K for a 50 mas beam)
This is sufficient to complete our science goal.
Furthermore, we have confirmed we are NOT surface brightness limited while using these long baselines by using our models to map the structure of these channles. In the channels where emission peaks at 4.5 mJy/beam/channel we find an integrated flux of 12 mJy/channel covering an area of 100 mas^2, equating to a temperature of 27.5 K. We fully detect this emission.

Here the data rate is 24.41 MB/s. This is approximately double the limit of 12 MB/s. As noted in the previous sections we require a spectral resolution of at least 0.66 km/s to achieve complete our science goal and a bandwidth of 937.5 GHz in order to fully cover the CH3CN ladders and numerous methonal lines we target and return a good continuum bandwidth.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Probing the rotating infalling envelope with 130K gas
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Using Band 6 and a setup focussing on the two simultaneously detectable CH3CN ladders (J=12-11 and J=13-12) we can probe the 3D velocity and temperature structure. Using the 1st unblended line in the ladder K=3, we can map the rotating and infalling material

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Given the line we target is 6 km/s wide we can sufficiently resolve the velocity structure with a spectral resolution of 0.66 km/s. As we are probing two methyl cyanide ladders we also require the 937.5 MHz bandwidth. Therefore the ideal setup is the 937.5 MHz bandwidth with 0.66 km/s spectral resoltuion.
In addition we also target a range of methanol lines in the other two free basebands. From our previous observations 0.66 km/s spectral resolution is sufficient and also having a bandwidth of 937.5 MHz allows us to maximise the coverage of many methonal lines in the same band and give us a reasonable line free bandwidth for the continuum emission.

In our previous SMA-VEX data the K=3 line is the most extended but does not have emission larger than 2'' scales that is related to the envelope around W33A (Figure 2B of the proposal PDF). We therefore do not need to image scales bigger than this. Furthermore, we already have SMA data covering scales larger scales (Published in Galvan-Madrid et al 2010).
Our previous data was 0.5'' resolution with the SMA-VEX configuration. Here we require 0.15" which is over 3 time higher. This will allow us to understand the morphology of the infall and rotation as this is only marginally resolved in our SMA data (Figure 2B). With this resolution we are able to fully map the morphology and pin down the infall and rotation in the model with these tighter constraints while having a MRS of 2'' means we will not resolve out any of the important envelope to disk spatial scales.
Furthermore we will now also be able to start to resolve the K>3 lines which were mainly unresolved in our SMA data. Hence we can map the rotation, infall and temperature structure spatially.

For this science goal we will map the rotation and infall of the envelope onto the disk of W33A with a resolution of 150 mas. To do this we focus on the CH3CN J=12-11 K=3 line (Eu = 130 K) that is the first unblended line in the ladder. We detect this strongly in our previous SMA-VEX observations with 0.5'' resolution (see Figure 1 of the attached proposal PDF). Note, as below, 0.6 km/s channels are sufficient to fully map the velocity structure.
The K=3 line is resolved in our previous work. The peak in a 0.5'' beam in a 0.6 km/s channel is 90K as seen in Figure 1 of our proposal. This corresponds to ~1Jy. Assuming a uniform coverage the beam scaling is 0.5^2 / 0.15^2 = 11.1, and we expect the peak in a 150 mas ALMA beam to be 90 mJy/beam/channel. Using our comprehensive 3D line model, which reproduces the SMA data, we find a peak of 80 mJy/beam/channel, close to that calculated indicating the emission is roughly uniform.
Now, to fully map the velocity structure (rotation and infall) we need to image channels which peak at 15% of this, i.e. the peak of the outer velocity channels = 80 * 0.15 = 12 mJy/beam/channel
To image these with a S/N of 5 we require a sensitivity of 2.4 mJy/beam/channel.

Here the data rate is 24.41 MB/s. This is approximately double the limit of 12 MB/s. As noted in the previous sections we require a spectral resolution of at least 0.66 km/s to achieve complete our science goal and a bandwidth of 937.5 GHz in order to fully cover the CH3CN ladders and numerous methonal lines we target and return a good continuum bandwidth.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Probing the rotating infall onto the disk using 230K gas
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Using Band 7 and a setup focussing on the CH3CN (J=19-18 ) ladder we can probe the 3D velocity and temperature structure closer to the source tracing material likely falling onto the disk itself. Using the K=3 and K=6 lines we can map the rotating and infalling material from 230 to 425K and examine if the pattern changes with spatial scale.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Given the line we target is 6 km/s wide we can sufficiently resolve the velocity structure with a spectral resolution of 0.48 km/s. As we are probing a methyl cyanide ladder we also require the 937.5 MHz bandwidth to cover this. Therefore the ideal setup is the 937.5 MHz bandwidth with 0.48 km/s spectral resoltuion when the spectral averaging of a factor of 2 is selected.
In addition we also target a range of methanol lines in one free baseband, and SO2 and SiO, a hot core and outflow shock tracer respectively, in the others. From our previous observations 0.5 km/s spectral resolution is sufficient to resolve these. Using a bandwidth of 937.5 MHz in for these lines also allows us to maximise the coverage of many methanol lines in the same band and achieve a reasonable bandwidth of line free emission for the continuum.

In our previous SMA-VEX data the Band 6 CH3CN J=12=11 K=3 line is the most extended but does not have emission larger than 2'' scales that is related to the envelope around W33A (Figure 2B of the proposal PDF). Now we are targetting the Band 7, CH3CN J=19-18 K=3 line which probes hotter material (230 K) and will be more compact than that in Band 6. We therefore do not need to image scales bigger than 2''
As our previous data was 0.5'' resolution with the SMA-VEX configuration. Here we require 0.15" which is over 3 time higher. This will allow us to understand the morphology of the infall and rotation and provide a direct comparison with the Band 6 science goal probing gas at 130 K. With this resolution we are able to fully map the morphology and pin down the infall and rotation of the hotter gas in the model with these tighter constraints. With a MRS of 2'' we will not resolve out any of the important envelope to disk spatial scales.
We will also be able to start resolving the K>3 lines which probe hotter materail closer to the protostar. Hence we can map the rotation, infall and temperature structure spatially.

For this science goal we will map the rotation and infall of the envelope onto the disk of W33A with a resolution of 150 mas of the hotter gas than our Band 6 observations. To do this we focus on the CH3CN J=19-18 K=3 line that is the first unblended line in the ladder we target in Band 7 and has a upper energy level of 230 K.
Using our comprehensive 3D line model, which reproduces the SMA data in Band 6, we find a peak of 100 mJy/beam/channel for the CH3CN J=19-18 K=3 line in Band 7. Here in our model given the frequency the channels are narrower than in Band 6, so are ~0.5 km/s.
Now, to fully map the velocity structure (rotation and infall) we need to image channels which peak at 15% of this (as our Band 6 science goal indicates also), i.e. the peak of the outer velocity channels = 100 * 0.15 = 15 mJy/beam/channel
To image these channels with a S/N of 5 we require a sensitivity of 3.0 mJy/beam/channel.

The data rate reported here is 12.21 MB/s and only slightly over the limit of 12 MB/s. We have already reduced the spectral resolution by selecting spectral averaging of 2 for all spectral windows we have set up.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to fully trace the 3D velocity field of material accreting onto a newly forming massive protostar from envelope to disk scales for the first time. This study will open a new era in massive star formation as we simultaneously probe the geometry and kinematics of the hot infalling material from 5000 to 100 au. The target is a well studied massive young stellar object already having a rare combination of high resolution observations at mm (SMA-VEX ~0.5''), mid-IR (VLTI-MIDI) and near-IR (Gemini-LGS-AO). We have developed 3D radiative transfer models including infall from the outer rotating envelope (>1500 au) onto a compact Keplerian disk in order to match these data, predict what ALMA will see, and to interpret the new data. We propose to use the long baselines of ALMA to reveal the accretion disk on previously unaccessible scales and examine how the disk is fed from the infalling envelope.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
